conclusion: Analyze the setup involving lamps, rails, and conductor rod to calculate parameters like induced voltage and power.
Image shows two metal rails, L₁ and L₂, parallel on a horizontal plane with a conductor rod ab perpendicular to them and a uniform magnetic field B = 1 T directed vertically.
Conductor rod ab moves right at constant speed, creating changing magnetic flux through rails.
Magnetic flux through rails is product of magnetic induction (B) and area of rails (length l and width w).
Induced EMF in rails calculated using Faraday's law: \( \varepsilon = B \cdot l \cdot v \).
Power of lamp L₁ is given as 3W.
Using power equation \( P = \frac{V^2}{R} \), voltage across lamp L₁ is \( V_1 = \sqrt{3} \, \text{V} \).
Actual power of lamp L₂ calculated using induced EMF and resistance of lamp L₂: \( P_2 = \frac{(0.6v)^2}{1} = 0.36v^2 \, \text{W} \).
Since lamp L₁ just lights up, power of lamp L₂ is equal to power of lamp L₁: \( P_2 = 3 \, \text{W} \).
